awd_titl_txt: Deep-Learning for Galaxy Morphology in the Big Data Era
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomy is entering the Big Data era.  The wealth of data which will soon be available from massive surveys will be invaluable for understanding galaxy evolution.  However, extracting and interpreting information from enormously rich datasets is a challenge with no sufficiently efficient, demonstrated solutions to date.  This is a project to tailor Deep Learning algorithms, which have been used successfully in other fields where pattern recognition matters, to measure galaxy morphologies quickly and accurately.  The long-term goal is to develop algorithms which transform Big Data into Big Discovery in astrophysics.  All algorithms and classifications will be made available for more general use.  The principal researcher is committed to supporting scientists from under-represented groups, through hiring practices, teaching in the US and in other countries, and by helping to build the capacity for developing countries to produce cutting-edge science.

Morphology is a key observable for constraining galaxy formation models, but quantifying morphology is currently a time-consuming process, severely compromised by the big-data transition.  Deep Learning algorithms may be the answer.  In the first phase, algorithms will learn from the large set of morphological classifications available from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).  The next phase studies how to transfer the knowledge gained from SDSS into analysis of images from the Dark Energy Survey (DES).  The use of simulated images to accelerate the learning process will also be studied.  This is the first step towards the automated classification of other aspects of galaxy structure.  The long-term goal is to develop algorithms which transform Big Data into Big Discovery in astrophysics.  Work with Deep Learning derived morphologies will illustrate the data-to-discovery process.  Teaching expertise in using the SDSS and DES databases to visiting astronomers, educators and masters-level students will help to ensure a wider global impact of the investment in building these databases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes: Science

One of the main objectives of this project was to provide morphological classifications for galaxies from the Dark Energy Survey using supervised Deep Learning (DL) algorithms.The DES survey includes images of millions galaxies up to z ∼ 1 meaning that automated classifications are essential. This was a program for tailoring Deep Learning algorithms to measure galaxy morphologies quickly and accurately. We published a paper presenting our methodology. Along with the manuscript we made publicly available the morphological catalogue for 27 million galaxies within DES and some algorithms. This is the largest multi-band catalog of automated galaxy morphologies to date.

We also applied our DL algorithms to the MaNGA survey dataset. The MaNGA survey is an ambitious dataset of spatially resolved spectroscopy which is revolutionizing our understanding of galaxy formation.

The more reliable morphological classifications which our DL returns combined with the high quality spectra in the MaNGA survey allowed us to study gradients in age, metallicity, α-element abundance ratio and mass-to-light ratio (M*/L) of galaxies of different morphological type. This also allowed us to construct a cleaner picture of how angular momentum varies across a population of fixed morphological type.

We also analyzed/estimated the half mass radius (in addition to the half-light radius which is the typical measurement used in the literature) of MaNGA galaxies. It is well known that gradients in the stellar populations of galaxies can result in gradients in the stellar mass to light ratio, M∗/L. Such gradients imply that the distribution of the stellar mass and light are different. Variations in the stellar Initial Mass Function (IMF) can produce significant M∗/L gradients. We have shown for the first time that the fractional decrease in the half-mass compared to the half-light radius can be significant (a factor of two), much larger than the fractional M∗ increase (compared to M∗ computed without gradients), especially when the light is more centrally concentrated.

Finally, the structure of a galaxy is determined in part by the interplay between gravity and the nature of dark matter. In one of our papers we showed that estimates of the structure of galaxies potentially allows novel tests of both. We made the point that a factor of 2 change in the M*/L within galaxies, if unaccounted for, leads to biased constraints on the nature of gravity.

Our results put powerful constrains on galaxy formation models.

Outcomes: Broader Impacts

Most of our results reflect the large effort of my postdocs Helena Domı́nguez S?nchez and Berta Margalef-Bentabol (both female) who were supported by this grant.  Both postdocs have moved on to other positions in the field (one of which is tenure-track).

The Deep Learning morphology classifications for DES galaxies and related algorithms were made available through the DES website.

The PI spent two weeks working with visiting astronomers, educators and masters-level students at the International Centre for Theoretical Physics. This was unfortunately limited by the Covid pandemic.

The PI mentored some high-school students on small projects related to this proposal. One female student decided to study computer science and is now an undergraduate at UPenn.
